title: Welcome
text:
I specialize in mapping and monitoring forest ecosystems using advanced remote sensing technologies and geospatial analysis. My work focuses on understanding forest dynamics, carbon cycling, and ecosystem responses to environmental change.



Forest Ecosystem Monitoring: Leveraging satellite imagery and LiDAR data to track forest structure and composition
Carbon Science: Quantifying forest carbon stocks and understanding carbon dynamics in terrestrial ecosystems
Geospatial Analysis: Developing innovative methods for analyzing large-scale environmental datasets
Climate Change Impacts: Investigating how forests respond to changing environmental conditions




As a Remote Sensing Scientist at Renoster Systems and Research Assistant at Oregon State University, I develop cutting-edge approaches for monitoring forest ecosystems at scale. I also provide consulting services through Spatial Informatics Group and Pachama Inc., applying remote sensing expertise to real-world conservation and climate challenges.

title: Hobby Projects
text:
Here are some hobby projects I’ve worked on in my spare time.



A Python port of the c-factor BRDF logic for Google Earth Engine. This algorithm corrects Landsat reflectance data to nadir BRDF-adjusted reflectance (NBAR) using fixed, MODIS-derived BRDF spectral model parameters.
The Problem: The edges of a Landsat scene have slightly different orientations with respect to the sensors, resulting in “striping” along the WRS2 scene boundaries. This algorithm “flattens” each scene so you can obtain large-area, wall-to-wall composites without variation along the scene boundaries.
My Contribution: This is the first publicly available Python port of the c-factor BRDF algorithm. I created a one-to-one comparison with the original JavaScript implementation and verified that this logic produces identical results.
The c-factor BRDF algorithm was originally developed by Roy et al. (2016) and implemented in JavaScript by Daniel Wiell and Erik Lindquist of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
Links: - GitHub Repository - Comparison of JS vs Python Outputs - Original JavaScript Implementation
Reference: Roy, D. P., Zhang, H. K., Ju, J., Gomez-Dans, J. L., Lewis, P. E., Schaaf, C. B., … & Kovalskyy, V. (2016). A general method to normalize Landsat reflectance data to nadir BRDF adjusted reflectance. Remote Sensing of Environment, 176, 255-271.
Technologies: Python, Google Earth Engine, Landsat, MODIS




For a complete list of my academic publications, please visit my Google Scholar profile.

More projects coming soon! Feel free to check out my GitHub for additional code and collaborations.
